Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition: make believe \make" be*lieve`\, v. i. To pretend; -- often used with that, but often having the that omitted; as, he made believe he didn't hear her; or he made believe that he didn't hear her. [PJC]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
make-believe \make"-be*lieve`\, n. A feigning to believe, as in the play of children; a mere pretense; a fiction; an invention. ``Childlike make-believe.'' --Tylor. [1913 Webster]
To forswear self-delusion and make-believe. --M. Arnold. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Make-believe \Make"-be*lieve`\, a. 1. Feigned; insincere. ``Make-believe reverence.'' --G. Eliot. [1913 Webster]
2. Imaginary; as, the child had a make-believe friend to whom he often talked. [PJC]
make believe v : represent fictitiously, as in a play, or pretend to be or act like; "She makes like an actress" [syn: {make}, {pretend}]

make-believe adj : imagined as in a play; "the make-believe world of theater"; "play money"; "dangling their legs in the water to catch pretend fish" [syn: {pretend}] n 1: imaginative intellectual play [syn: {pretense}, {pretence}] 2: the enactment of a pretense; "it was just pretend" [syn: {pretend}]
